items.author: Kirk Honeycutt
items.content: For Christopher Nolan to turn Batman Begins into such a smart, gritty, brooding, visceral experience is astonishing. Truly, Batman does begin again.

items.author: Kim Newman
items.content: Significantly grittier than previous Bat-beginnings, this finds new things to do with, and say about, a character who's been around since 1938.

items.author: Scott Foundas
items.content: Of course, a Batman movie is nothing without a Bruce Wayne, and, by a mile, Bale is the best of a lot that has ranged from the square-jawed slapstick of Adam West to the more dedbonair stylings of Michael Keaton, Val Kilmer and George Clooney.

items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: The buildup is steadily engrossing. That's because Nolan keeps the emphasis on character, not gadgets. Gotham looks lived in, not art-directed.

items.author: Ty Burr
items.content: In Batman Begins, Christian Bale gives us the best Bruce Wayne that has ever graced the screen.

items.author: Todd McCarthy
items.content: Ambitious, well made but not exactly rousing.

items.author: Michael Atkinson
items.content: Nolan and his co-screenwriter David Goyer can only press the big buttons so hardâ€”it's still an old-school superhero summer movie, the plotting tortuous, the characters relegated to one-scene-one-emotion simplicity, the digitized action a never ending club mix of chases and mano a manos.

items.author: Ken Tucker
items.content: Begins, at two-hours-plus, is a nonstarter.

items.author: David Denby
items.content: The young Welsh-born actor Christian Bale is a serious fellow, but the most interesting thing about him--a glinting sense of superiority--gets erased by the dull earnestness of the screenplay, and the filmmakers haven't developed an adequate villain for him to go up against.

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: Nolan's effort is not dishonorable, but what it needs, and doesn't have, is a Joker in the deck--some antic human antimatter to give it the giddy lift of perversity that a bunch of impersonal explosions, no matter how well managed, can't supply.
